sentences: Kevin Graham Ogilvie (born December 5, 1962), known professionally as Nivek Ogre, is a Canadian musician, performance artist and actor, best known for his work with the industrial music group Skinny Puppy, which he co-founded with cEvin Key.
Since 1982, he has served as Skinny Puppy's primary lyricist and vocalist, occasionally providing instrumentation and samples.
In 2001, he formed the electronic music group ohGr along with longtime collaborator Mark Walk.
Originally named W.E.L.T., ohGr has released five studio albums since 2001, three of which have placed on Billboard's Dance/Electronic Albums chart.
The Genetic Opera, as well as Harper Alexander in the comedy-horror film entitled 2001 Maniacs: Field of Screams.

In 2014, he starred in the Canadian film Queen of Blood.
Ogre was born on December 5, 1962 in Calgary, Alberta, Canada.
In 1982, he attempted to start a record distribution company using borrowed money, a venture that ultimately failed.
Along with Bill Leeb (Wilhelm Shroeder), Ogre and Key produced the EP Remission in 1984 and released it through the newly established Nettwerk label.
Next to follow were two full-length albums, Bites in 1985 and Mind: The Perpetual Intercourse in 1986, the latter of which spawned their first single, "Dig It".

1988's VIVIsectVI, written as "a biting commentary on animal rights", spawned the single "Testure" which peaked at no. 19 on Billboard's Dance Club Songs chart.
In 1994, Skinny Puppy completed the master tapes for the album.
Ogre quit Skinny Puppy in June 1995, two months before Goettel died from a heroin overdose.
He joined the Banff Centre as an artist-in-residence in spring 2000 before reuniting with Key to perform at the Doomsday Festival in Dresden as Skinny Puppy.

In 2013, inspired by the news that their music had been used for torture at Guantanamo Bay detention camp, they released the album Weapon.
In early 2014, Ogre and Key sent the US government an invoice for $666,000 for the use of their music at the camp.
In 2015, they embarked on the Down the Sociopath tour with Youth Code through North America.

"What makes ohGr different from Skinny Puppy", Ogre explained to Westword in 2011, "is that Skinny Puppy focuses on sound design with lyrics laid on top, while ohGr bases its music around lyrics".

He stated further: "When we're performing live, with ohGr, we strip back a lot of the electronics and the stuff that doesn't need to be there...All the guitars out, all the bass out, when it's played live, and a lot of the keyboards are played live, too".ohGr released their fifth album, Tricks, on June 18, 2018.
The album had been intended for release on October 31, 2017, but the release date was pushed back due to a mastering error.
The band promoted the album with a 32 date North American tour and included three dates for the 2018 Cold Waves festival, which they had performed in the year prior while supporting KMFDM.
In January 2019, amid similar stories from other bands, Walk told Billboard that PledgeMusic had owed the band $100,000 in funds raised during the campaign.
Ogre's first collaboration with Al Jourgensen was in 1987 during the recording of the song "Show Me Your Spine" for the film RoboCop.
